Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT0801-COX1stlede 
    

      CoxNet Cox News Service budget 1stlede
      FOR TUESDAY, August 1, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Adds: FBN-MILLER-DEBUT, ATL-MACY'S, FLOYD-AFTERMATH, GOP-BUSH,
GOP-NOTEBOOK, CVN-OPENING, CVN-BAXTER, RAP-MUSIC, BREAST-CANCER,
CVN-BUSH-FALL, CVN-BUSH-RANCH, FBC-GAFOOTBALL, DELTA-VOTE,
MOTHER-REUNION, CLINTON-VISIT, SPIDERMAN-TRIAL

   Deletes: CREDIT-CARDS, POWER-DEAL, POWER-HISTORY, POWER REACTION

   NATIONAL

   FLOYD-AFTERMATH _ ROCKY MOUNT, N.C. _ Hurricane Floyd Survivor's
Committee and the Workers and Community Aid and Relief Project
(RAP) hold a press conference to voice concerns over FEMA and North
Carolina putting flood survivors on an industrial waste
dump.(Burritt, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MOTHER-REUNION _ ATLANTA _ Kimberly Howard last saw her son on a
winter day in 1989. He was a curly-headed 6-year-old, full of the
wonder and excitement of a child about to board a plane with his
father. Weeks later, her ex-husband called to say he would never
bring their son back from a trip to his native Saudi Arabia. ``That
was the day my descent into hell began,'' says Howard, 42. For the
next 11 years, the former Atlantan hoped, despaired, fumed and
fought to get her son back. Now, in what Howard's family calls a
miracle, Laith Khayyat _ who will be 18 in October _ is due to
arrive Tuesday night in the United States. ``I'm numb,'' Howard
said. ``I thought I'd never see him again.'' (Hansen, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   POWER-DEAL _ Floriday Power and Light will buy New Orleans-based
Entergy in $14 billion stock and cash deal, creating the

   largest power company in the nation. The new company will be

   headquartered in Juno Beach, and Entergy CEO Wayne Leonard will
be in charge. (Ostrowski, Circelli, Palm Beach Post)

   POWER-HISTORY _ Florida Power & Light grew up with the

   state of Florida. A look back at its origins, and its position
now as it moves into national prominence. (Ostrowski, Circelli,
Palm Beach Post

   POWER REACTION _ Officials and FPL workers are mostly upbeat
about the merger. (Martinez, Circelli. Palm Beach Post)

   CLINTON-VISIT _ President Clinton visits Palm Beach to raise

   money for democrats. (BENNETT, Palm Beach Post)

   SPIDERMAN-TRIAL _ The Spiderman criminal trial begins today.

   Prosecutors and his attorney are having a hard time picking
jurors

   because they've all heard of him. One juror even picked him out.

   (Douthat, Palm Beach Post)

   CONVENTION

   GOP-BUSH _ COLUMBUS, Ohio _ George W. Bush courts a crucial
state as he continues his march to the convention. He holds rallies
Monday in Dayton and Columbus, Ohio. (Heath, Austin
American-Statesman)

   CVN-OPENING _ PHILADELPHIA _ Opening their national convention
with a theme of inclusion, Republican bring a parade of women and
minorities to the podium Monday. The main speakers are Laura Bush,
wife of the nominee, and Colin Powell, former chairman of the Joint
Chiefs of Staff. (Herman, Cox News Service)

   CVN-GADE _ Members of the Georgia delegation take part in a
tribute for the late Sen. Paul Coverdell. Earlier they hosted Mack
Mattingly and Newt Gingrich at a breakfast. (Eversley, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   CVN-SHADOW _ PHILADELPHIA _ What evil lurks in the hearts of
Republicans (and Democrats)? Only the shadow convention knows. This
alternative gathering, engineered by political maverick Arianna
Huffington, is skewering both parties from the fringes of political
thought. (Dart, Cox Washington Bureau) 20''

   CVN-TECHNOLOGY _ PHILADELPHIA _ From the moment House Speaker
Dennis Hastert opens the proceedings via a remote hookup, this
Republican National Convention will feature a raft of high-tech
touches. (Glass, Cox Washington Bureau). 25''

   CVN-BLACKS _ PHILADELPHIA _ The Republican party says it's tired
of its age old image of being unfriendly toward minorities in
America. During this election cycle in particular, the party is
pushing African-American candidates in three congressional
districts, one in Georgia, one in Florida and another in New York.
African Americans active in the party say the GOP serves as a
better match toward traditional, conservative African-American
philosophies. (Eversley, Cox News Service)

   GOP-NOTEBOOK _ PHILADELPHIA _ A reporter's notebook of
Republican National Convention briefs. (Staff, Cox News Service)

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   CVN-BAXTER _ Political column from the GOP convention from Cox
columnist Tom Baxter. (Baxter, Cox News Service)

   CVN-BUSH-FALL _ Political strategist Karl Rove lays out Bush's
plans to win the White House this fall. (Herman, Cox News Service)
20''

   CVN-BUSH-RANCH _ Former president George Bush is reportedly

   seeking land near Gov. George W. Bush's home in Crawford, Texas.

   (Bahadur, Waco Herald-Tribune)

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ ``I AM NOT SUPERWOMAN!? Gail
yells into the phone plastered against my ear. ``A pox upon Martha
Stewart!'' Rather than ask what has tilted her day into a spell of
the nasties, I join in. ``YEAH! And Helen Trent and Our Gal Sunday,
too!'' The Cape Cod end of the connection falls silent for a just a
second while she thinks that one over. ``Who's that?'' she asks. I
knew she would. Gail's 12 years younger than I am. (Schuett, Cox
News Service) MOVED.

   LANE-COLUMN _ DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. _ It was early in the a.m. and
something woke me. A sound. The faint plastic-on-plastic tap of
computer keys. It was only my daughter reacting to a federal court
order. Knowing she had only a day left to use Napster, she was up
late downloading the last few songs. Around the planet, a record
number of computer users were hooked up to Napster. (Lane, Daytona
Beach News-Journal) MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   BIZMAGS _ A rundown of the week's financial press. (Walker,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   ATL-MACY'S _ After five years of marketing it, Federated
Department Stores has sold the Macy's downtown Atlanta location. A
New York real estate company will convert the space to a
telecom/high-tech building and lease about 200,000 sq. ft. back to
Federated to operate the store. (Staff, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   DELTA-VOTE _ The National Mediation Board has ordered a rerun of
last spring's big union election at Delta Air Lines. The board
cited two procedural glitches and found that Delta forced some
employees to attend meetings that should have been voluntary.
(Staff, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TECH-PLAYGEAR _ The latest in digital game gear. This week:
TremorPak Plus. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-WORKGEAR _ The latest in digital work gear. This week:
Magnalite Map Kits. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-HOMEGEAR _ The latest in digital home gear. This week: iMac
DV Special Edition. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-GAMER _ Games for the console and desktop aimed at the
moderate to advanced gamer. This week: Project S.W.A.R.M (Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-CENTERPIECE _ Weekly centerpiece on personal technology,
from products to trends to advancements. This week: Attachment to
technology gadgets. (Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECHNOBUDDY_ Popular column about personal computing written for
the average user. This week: Webvan visits Technobuddy. (Husted,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECH-GAMEZONE _ Review of the popular video game ``Who Wants to
Be a Millionaire.'' (Carvell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   HEAD-TO-HEAD _ Head to Head is an occasional feature in which
Michael Carvell and Troy Oxford will offer different viewpoints
about a popular video game title. This week: `Virtua Tennis.'
(Carvell and Oxford, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECH-TOOLS _ Software reviews. This week: SoomSoom. (Warner,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   NETWATCH _ What's new on the Web. This week: Oxygen channel.
(Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECH-SAVVY _ Question and answer column focusing on using
computers and other technology as tools to get jobs done.
(Cleere/Rudd, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECH-FAMILY _ Weekly column focusing on family related computer
technology. This week: Computer ideas for kids with summer boredom.
(Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   LIFESTYLE

   HEALTH

   BREAST-CANCER _ WASHINGTON _ Women over 80 frequently do not get
the full range of treatment for early stage breast cancer,
according to a new study conducted by the Lombardi Cancer Center at
Georgetown University Medical Center. (Lipman, Cox News Service)

   BRAIN STUDY _ The new Center for Brain Research at Wright State
University's School of Medicine will encourage collaboration among
scientists who study different aspects of the brain's functions in
health and disease. (Staff, Dayton Daily News)

   OBESITY-WOMEN _ Obese women avoid going to the doctor because
they're overweight and know they'll just get a lecture to lose
weight. This despite the fact that they're at high risk for cancer
and heart disease and other problems because they are overweight.
Obesity is the only life-threatening health condition doctors don't
try to treat effectively: usually they send women home with a
admonition to lose weight, but no effective means to do it. What
overweight consumers need to know to get the health care they need
from doctors. (Lore, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTO

   BODIES-SPANISH _ ``Our Bodies, Ourselves,'' what many women
consider the Bible of women's health references, has been rewritten
in Spanish and revised to be culturally sensitive for Hispanic
women. (McKenna, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   CONSUMERQ&A _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Consumer Q&A. (Greig, Austin
American-Statesman) (l, a). MOVED.

   ATLANTA-GUIDE _ Here's a twist on the traditional guidebook:
Fodor's has just released ``CityGuide Atlanta,'' part of a series
of seven guides aimed at residents, not tourists. We assume Atlanta
was added to the series ``written by locals who know their cities
inside and out'' because of the massive number of newcomers who
settle there yearly. (Hamilton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 8''

   NEWS FOR KIDS

   NFK-CHECKITOUT _ A brief on a new web site, TV show or event for
kids. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   NFK-NEWSFLASH _ Three or four briefs of world and national news,
written for kids to understand. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED.

   NFK-CONVENTIONS _ A feature about a celebrity kid, kid's event,
or big news story explained for kids, for papers' kids or family
pages. This week: Presidential conventions. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   NEWSSTAND _ Periodicals on the newsstands this week. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   RAP-MUSIC _ The rap music generation gap. There I am, doing my
morning workout at the gym, when I finally decide to pop the tape
I've been avoiding into my cassette player. It's Eminem's
chart-topping The Marshall Mathers LP, and if you've read any of
the headlines concerning this Michigan-born rapper, you'd
understand my hesitation. (Passy, Palm Beach Post) WITH
ILLUSTRATION MOVED

   SPORTS

   BBN-BRAVES-ROAD _ The Atlanta Braves have fattened their record
on losing teams and again have the best record in baseball but now
they hit the road to face Arizona, St. Louis and Cincinnati.
(Rogers, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BBO-TRADES-DEADLINE _ The baseball trade deadline (for players
who will still be eligible for the postseason) is at 4 p.m. Monday
EDT. A look at any last-minute moves (Stinson, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   FBN-MILLER-DEBUT _ A critique/review of the debut of Dennis
Miller on the Monday Night Football crew as it works an exhibition
game, the Hall of Fame game between New England and San Francisco.
(Rogers, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 12''

   FBC-GAFOOTBALL _ Continuing coverage of the Georgia football
phone scandal. Filing open records request in search of names of
players involved, penalties the school imposed on itself and what
got filed with NCAA in the case. (Schlabach, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EST and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

   Night news editor Todd C. Duncan, 404-582-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

tduncan(at)coxnews.com
